item.title: useFlash
item.content:encoded:
This animation perform a flashing to the component.

Options object:

useFlash receives an object for custom configurations, like:

propdescriptiontypedefault value
durationthe duration of every single flash, it is a ms valuenumber300
startif true will start the flashingbooltrue
timesspecify how many times it will flashnumber2
infinitymake the flashing never stop!boolfalse

Example:

flash.jsx
function App(props) {
  const [{ animation, state }, toggle] = useFlash({
    start: true,
    infinity: true,
    duration: 600,
  });


  return (
    <div>
      <div
        {...props}
        style={{ backgroundColor: 'orange', padding: 20, marginBottom: 20 }}
        css={`
          animation: ${animation};
        `}
      >
        Attention!
      </div>
      <Button
        onClick={() => toggle(!state)}
        skin={state ? 'danger' : 'success'}
      >
        {state ? 'Stop' : 'Start'} flashing
      </Button>
    </div>
  );
}


render(App);

item.title: useFade
item.content:encoded:
This animation perform a fade to the component, you can specify if it will be a fade in, fade out or both.

You can also control the render with the animation state property.

Options object:

useFade receives an object for custom configurations, like:

propertydescriptiontypedefault value
startOnRenderstart fadeIn on first component renderbooltrue
durationthe duration of the fade effect, it is a ms valuenumber300
fadeInapply the fade in animation when the animation state is truebooltrue
fadeOutapply the fade out animation when the animation state is falsebooltrue

Returned values:

useFade hook return a pair of values, the animation object and a function to toggle the animation state.

animation properties:

propertydescription
animationanimation css property value
stateanimation state value (after fade ends)
instantStateanimation state value that updates right before it changes (without waiting the fade to end)

toggle function:

Second value returned from useFade hook is a function to toggle the fade animation, the initial state value is true (if you didn’t change the startOnRender property) and it will perform a fade in animation by default.

If you want to change the animation state to false to perform a fade out, just call the function passing false as an argument.

Example:

fade.jsx
function App() {
  /** default options object */
  const options = {
    startOnRender: true,
    duration: 300,
    fadeIn: true,
    fadeOut: true,
  };
  const [{ animation, state, instantState }, toggleFade] = useFade(options);


  return (
    <div style={{ height: 200 }}>
      <Button
        skin={instantState ? 'danger' : 'success'}
        onClick={() => toggleFade(!state)}
      >
        {instantState ? 'hide' : 'show'} card
      </Button>
      <p>
        The animation state is: <strong>{state.toString()}</strong>
      </p>
      <p>
        The animation instantState is:{' '}
        <strong>{instantState.toString()}</strong>
      </p>
      {state && (
        <Card
          css={`
            animation: ${animation};
          `}
        >
          <Card.Content>Frigobar card</Card.Content>
        </Card>
      )}
    </div>
  );
}


render(App);
Take a look that we are using the state property to control the render and
make sure that our Card component only unmounts when fadeOut finishes.

item.title: Menu
item.content:encoded:
Menu component

.jsx
render(() => {
  const buttonRef = useRef(null);
  const [open, toggleOpen] = useState(false);


  return (
    <div>
      <Menu
        anchorElement={buttonRef}
        open={open}
        handleClickAway={() => {
          toggleOpen(false);
        }}
      >
        <Menu.Item>Item 1</Menu.Item>
        <Menu.Item>Item 2</Menu.Item>
      </Menu>
      <Button ref={buttonRef} onClick={() => toggleOpen(true)}>
        Open menu
      </Button>
    </div>
  );
});

item.title: Getting Started
item.content:encoded:
Frigobar is a simple component library built with React and styled-components.

Install

You can install Frigobar using either of the methods below.

For npm users:

npm install @frigobar/core styled-components --save

For Yarn users:

yarn add @frigobar/core styled-components

styled-components is a peerDependency of all frigobar packages, so, make sure to install styled-components aswell.

Usage

It’s very easy to start using frigobar in your react application:

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import { Button } from '@frigobar/core';
function App() {
  return <Button>Button</Button>;
}
ReactDOM.render(<App />, document.getElementById('root'));

item.title: Getting Started
item.content:encoded:
Easily add CSS animation to your react styled components via custom hooks.

All the animations are created with CSS Animations && @keyframes

Installation

You can install @frigobar/animation using either of the methods below.

For npm users:

$ npm install @frigobar/animation --save

For Yarn users:

$ yarn add @frigobar/animation

An important note is that the styled-components is a peerDependency see why, if you dont have styled-components installed you’ll need to install.

Usage

You can simply import the desired animation from the package and use it in any component.

Make sure to install babel-plugin-styled-components to use the css prop and easily add the animation css rule and value.

Example:

import React from 'react';
import { useFade } from '@frigobar/animation';
const Button = props => {
  const [{ animation }] = useFade({
    startOnRender: true,
  });
  return (
    <button
      {...props}
      css={`
        animation: ${animation};
      `}
    />
  );
};
export default Button;

Animations

Every hook have an options object to customize some behavior of it, like duration, when the animation starts, check current animation state, etc.

Also, provides a toggle function to change the state of the animation.

Here is the list with all the current animations provided by this package.

  • useFade - Fade (in / out) effect
  • useFlash - Flash effect
